citation.article-title: Bifidobacterium ruminantium sp. nov. and Bifidobacterium merycicum sp. nov. from the rumens of cattle.

p.s: Description of Bifidobacterium merycicum sp. nov.
Bifidobacterium merycicum (me.ry´ci.cum. Gr, n. meryx [implied by verb merykazo], rumen; N. L. adj. merycicum, pertaining to the rumen)
Gram-positive, nonmotile, nonsporeforming, irregularly shaped rods that are 2.0 to 5.0 μm long and are sometimes arranged in pairs which form angles (Fig. 1 through 8).
Surface colonies on Trypticase-Phytone-yeast extract agar are soft, smooth, convex, circular with entire margins, cream to white, and glistening (Fig. 13).
Anaerobic.
Carbon dioxide has no effect upon oxygen sensitivity, but it enhances anaerobic growth.
The optimum temperature for growth is 38 to 42°C.
No growth occurs below 25°C or at 45°C and above.
The optimum initial pH is 6.5 to 6.9.
Growth is delayed at pH 6.3 or 7.2.
No growth occurs at pH 4.5 or 8.
Arabinose, raffinose, sucrose, glucose, xylose, melibiose, maltose, lactose, starch, galactose, dextrin, and ribose are fermented.
Mannitol, mannose, melezitose, sorbitol, trehalose, glycerin, rhamnose, gluconate, and lactate are not fermented.
Salicin and inulin are not fermented or, occasionally, are fermented slowly.
Fructose is weakly fermented.
Cellobiose fermentation is variable.
The molar ratio of lactic acid to acetic acid from the fermentation of glucose ranges from 1:2 to 1:5.
No gas, propionic acid, or butyric acid is produced.
Catalase or pseudocatalase (hemin) is not produced.
Nitrate is not reduced.
Indole is not produced.
The G+C content of the DNA is 59 mol% (strains Ru769, Ru915BT, and Ru919) or 60 mol% (strain Ru767) (as determined by the thermal denaturation method).
The DNA of this species exhibits little or no relatedness to the DNA of any other Bifidobacterium species.
The type strain is strain Ru915B (= ATCC 49391), which was isolated from bovine rumen.
